{{Infobox company | name = Accounting Technicians Ireland | logo = | type = | foundation = [IRL] (1983) | company_slogan = | location = [[Dublin]], Ireland | key_people = vice-president: Aidan Collins, president: Ann Campbell Crombie | industry = [[Accountancy]] and finance | members = 4,500 (students: 5,800) | homepage ={{url|http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/}} }}
'''Accounting Technicians Ireland''' (formerly IATI) is a professional body for Accounting Technicians on the island of [[Ireland]]. They have over 10,000 members and students in the Republic of Ireland and in Northern Ireland.
The organisation was established in 1983 by representatives of the [[Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland]] (ICAI) and the Irish Institute of Accounting Technicians (IIAT). Accounting Technicians Ireland was originally called '''The Institute of Accounting Technicians in Ireland'''.
The Accounting Technicians Ireland qualification combines professional exams with practical work experience. The Accounting Technicians Ireland diploma is divided into two parts, each of which is a qualification in its own right: * Certificate for Accounting Technicians (1 year) * Diploma for Accounting Technicians (2 years)
As members of the Accounting Technicians Ireland body, individuals are entitled to use the letters MIATI after their name. After eight years members may be eligible to apply for fellow membership. Fellow members use the designation FIATI after their name. Other professional accountancy bodies recognise the qualification and offer exemptions from their examination to Accounting Technicians Ireland graduates.
Accounting Technicians Ireland is a not-for-profit organisation. They are a partner body of Chartered Accountants Ireland and an associate member of the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC). They have offices in Dublin and Belfast and links with local networks throughout Ireland.
Accounting Technicians Ireland is the trading name for the Institute of Accounting Technicians in Ireland Limited.<ref>[http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/About_Us/Who_are_Accounting_Technicians_Ireland.html Who are Accounting Technicians Ireland]</ref><ref>[http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/About_Us/Mission_values.html Accounting Technicians Ireland Mission and Values]</ref>
==History== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year!! Important events |- | 1983 || Accounting Technicians Ireland is established. It is originally called The Institute of Accounting Technicians in Ireland (IATI) was set up by representatives of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland (ICAI) and the Irish Institute of Accounting Technicians (IIAT). IATI shares premises with ICAI, shortly thereafter moves to Pembroke Road. Noel Stewart is appointed IATI chairman, a post which he held for five years |- | 1985 || IATI holds its first graduation ceremony of new members. |- | 1988 || Gregory Orr is appointed IATI chairman, a post he held for three years. |- | 1991 || Ray Gordon is appointed IATI chairman, and goes on to become the longest serving IATI chairman, holding the position for seven years. |- | 1994 || IATI is granted Charitable Status by the Revenue Commissioners, on the basis of its educational work. |- | 1996 || IATI changes its constitution at AGM, to ensure that members throughout the country are fairly represented on the board of directors. At least one director must be elected from Ulster and one from outside Leinster. A limit is also put on the length that directors may serve on the board. |- | 1997 || Ben Lynch retires as IATI Secretary, having filled that position for 15 years. |- | 1998 || Des Foley is appointed IATI chairman, the first elected IATI member to be appointed to the position. |- | 1999 || Angela Paisley becomes the first woman to be appointed IATI chairman. |- | 2000 || IATI's job placement service is registered as a limited company and begins trading independently of IATI under the name IATI Placement Service Limited. |- | 2002 || For the first time, IATI employs its own staff which were previously seconded from ICAI. Gay Sheehan is appointed as the Institute's first chief executive. IATI changes its constitution at AGM, to allow members to offer bookkeeping and non-regulated services to the public. |- | 2005 || IATI moves to new premises in Pembroke Road, Dublin 4. |- | 2006 || IATI Placement Service Limited adopts the trading name IATI Recruitment. IATI successfully applies for ISO 9001:2000 accreditation – the first accounting body of its kind in Ireland to gain this distinction. |- | 2007 || IATI changes its constitution at AGM, to provide for a Disciplinary Process, to be applied in cases of complaints against IATI members. |- | 2007/08 || The Director of Education, Director of Marketing and IT Project Manager join the CEO to form a senior management team. The first phase of the new syllabus and self-production of manuals is launched. |- | 2008 || IATI moves to temporary premises in Burlington Road, Dublin 4. IATI celebrates its 25th anniversary and surpasses 5,000 members for the first time. |- | 2009 || IATI changes its name to become Accounting Technicians Ireland and is formally launched by the Minister of State for Trade & Commerce, Billy Kelleher TD on 24thJune 2009. Accounting Technicians Ireland relocates headquarters to new premises on Pearse Street with partners Chartered Accountants Ireland. The Accounting Technicians Professional Education programme is launched. For the first time students can study directly with Accounting Technicians Ireland. |- | 2010|| Accounting Technicians Ireland secures recognition at Level 5 on the Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF) in the UK. The new class of fellow membership is launched for more experienced members. |}<ref>[http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/About_Us/History.html Accounting Technicians Ireland – History]</ref>
==Organisational structure== Accounting Technicians Ireland is managed and operated by a board of directors and 21 executive staff. The Board is responsible for managing the business of the organisation and for implementing a strategic vision.
The board of directors is made up of eight directors and a secretary. Four of these board directors are members of Accounting Technicians Ireland that have been elected and the other four board directors are nominated by their partner body, Chartered Accountants Ireland. The Board meets at intervals during the year and also for the AGM which is held in June.
The board of directors is led by the Officer Group. This group is made up of the President, Vice-President and Immediate Past President. These positions are only held by Board members and the term of office is one year.
The day-to-day management of Accounting Technicians Ireland is handled by Accounting Technicians Ireland COO Gillian Doherty who is supported by Director of Finance Christine Mulcahy.
Working under senior management the following departments support students' and members' needs: *Member Services *Student Services *IT *Finance and Administration
To further help students and members they provide a placement and careers service through Accounting Technicians Recruitment. The service keeps students and members up to date with accountancy vacancies in both practice and industry.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120722233215/http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/About_Us/How%20we%20operate.html Accounting Technicians Ireland – How we operate]</ref>
==Professional standards== Accounting Technicians Ireland has a Code of Professional Ethics and a set of Disciplinary Procedures, the purpose of which is to ensure confidence in the organisation and its members. The board of directors produced the Code of Professional Ethics for use by members and students, and it was adopted on 26 June 2007.<ref>[http://www.accountingtechniciansireland.ie/About_Us/Professional_standards.html Accounting Technicians Ireland – Professional Standards]</ref>
Accounting Technicians Ireland publish both their Code of Professional Ethics and Disciplinary Procedures on their website.
==Membership structure== Accounting Technicians Ireland has four levels of membership including a Student level. * '''Student Members''': all who have enrolled in an Accounting Technicians Ireland course and have yet to finish their final exams are classified as Student Members. They may be studying for the qualification by attending lecturers or through distance learning, or might have deferred sitting exams. * '''Affiliate Members''': Affiliate membership is open to all who have passed the Accounting Technicians Ireland exams but do not yet have the two years work experience required to complete the qualification and become Full members. Students can proceed straight to full membership once they pass their exams, if they have already gathered the required two years of relevant work experience. They are not required to become Affiliate Members first. * '''Full Members (MIATI)''': a Full Member of Accounting Technicians Ireland is someone who has completed the Diploma for Accounting Technicians qualification. They will have passed all their exams, completed at least two years approved work experience within an accounting or finance environment, and have been conferred at a graduation ceremony. They are entitled to use the professional letters MIATI after their name. * '''Fellow Members (FIATI)''': Fellow membership is open to anyone who has been a Full member of Accounting Technicians Ireland for eight years and has at least five years' experience of working in a senior position within their employment. They are entitled to use the professional letters FIATI to differentiate their senior experience and expertise within the accounting profession.

{{Infobox magazine |title = Air Cargo World | logo = Air Cargo World logo.jpg | logo_size = 190px |format = [[Magazine]] |firstdate ={{Start date|1942}} |publisher = JJ Hornblass |editor = Randy Woods |frequency = Monthly |circulation = 23,000 |company = [http://www.royalmedia.com Royal Media Group] |country = [[United States]] |based = [[Seattle, Washington]] |language = [[English language|English]] |website = {{URL|http://www.aircargoworld.com/}} }}
'''''Air Cargo World''''', published in the United States, is an air logistics magazine and is edited for shippers and others involved with the worldwide transport and delivery of perishables and manufactured goods.<ref name="Air Cargo World Media Kit">[http://www.aircargoworld-digital.com/aircargoworld/2013mk#pg1 Air Cargo World.] ''Air Cargo World Media Kit 2013". 2013. Retrieved September 10, 2013.</ref> Its readership consists of [[logistics]] professionals, [[airline]] and [[airport]] executives, [[freight forwarders]], importers, [[exporters]], and others who manage or purchase transportation products and services within the [[airfreight]] [[supply chain]].<ref name="Air Cargo World Media Kit" />
The monthly magazine’s editorial purpose is to provide the reader with insightful information by way of data analysis, feature articles, and in-depth coverage of events and trends affecting their business and the airfreight logistics industry. With more than 23,000 subscribers located in 184 countries, ''Air Cargo World'' maintains the largest circulation of any magazine in the air cargo category.<ref name="Air Cargo World Media Kit" />
''Air Cargo World'' conducts an annual Air Cargo Excellence Survey and holds the annual ACE Awards alongside the [[International Air Transport Association]]’s World Cargo Symposium conference.<ref name="Air Cargo Excellence">[http://www.aircargoworld.com/Air-Cargo-Excellence Air Cargo World.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902050954/http://www.aircargoworld.com/Air-Cargo-Excellence |date=2013-09-02 }} ''Air Cargo Excellence". 2013. Retrieved September 10, 2013.</ref>
The magazine also maintains a website with daily news items about developments in the air cargo industry. It publishes ''The Alert'', which recounts major news and is emailed to more than 23,000 subscribers throughout the world.
==History== [[Image:Air Cargo World cover, first issue.png|thumb|right|The first issue of ''Air Transportation'', whose name was later changed to ''Air Cargo World'', was published in 1942.]] ''Air Transportation'' was founded in [[New York City]] in October 1942 by John F. Budd as the world's first air cargo magazine. The magazine was launched while America was in its tenth month of [[World War II]], and the airfreight industry was in its infancy. A one-year subscription for the United States cost $5.
“''Air Transportation'' is not anti-ship, anti-rail or anti-truck,” Budd wrote in his opening editorial. “It is pro-air, because it believes that, sooner or later, cargo-by-air will be a mighty force with which every shipper should, in his own interest, be familiar.”
The [[United States Department of War]] was relying on aircraft to deliver war supplies, but the long-term future of air cargo as an independent industry was in question.
“Despite the hostility air cargo would have to face after the war, the need for it would lift air cargo into its proper place as a serious and vital form of transportation,” Budd wrote in an early ''Air Transportation'' editorial.
[[Image:Richard Malkin.jpg|thumb|left|Richard Malkin worked as an air cargo journalist for 60 years.He currently at 101 years of age works as contributing editor at Air Cargo News Flying Typers in New York.]] Richard Malkin, the first full-time air cargo journalist, worked in the field for 60 years, writing for what was then ''Air Transportation'' in the 1940s.<ref name="Industry in its infancy">[http://www.aircargoworld.com/Air-Cargo-News/2012/05/an-industry-in-its-infancy/307240 Air Cargo World.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829070729/http://www.aircargoworld.com/Air-Cargo-News/2012/05/an-industry-in-its-infancy/307240 |date=2013-08-29 }} ''An industry in its infancy". May 30, 2012. Retrieved September 10, 2013.</ref> In 1949, Malkin traveled to [[Frankfurt, Germany]] to write a series of articles about the [[Berlin Airlift]].<ref name="Industry in its infancy" />
“Passenger people will disagree with me, but almost from the beginning, I recognized air cargo as the more glamorous and romantic side of the business,” Malkin wrote in the 2002 anniversary issue of ''Air Cargo World''. “I spent the next six decades talking about getting out, yet never got around to doing it. Go figure.”<ref name="Industry in its infancy" />
The magazine eventually changed its name to ''Air Cargo''. In 1983, it became ''Air Cargo World'' and moved its office from New York to metro [[Atlanta]], where it has operated for 30 years.
In 2014, ''Air Cargo World'' was acquired <ref name="Royal Media acquires Air Cargo World">[http://aircargoworld.com/royal-media-acquires-air-cargo-world-10047.]"Royal Media acquires Air Cargo World," September 22, 2014</ref> by [http://www.royalmedia.com Royal Media Group], a New York-based information company.
==Air Cargo Excellence== The Air Cargo Excellence awards, known as the ACE Awards, are based on the Air Cargo Excellence Survey, which is carried out and published annually by ''Air Cargo World''.<ref name="Air Cargo Excellence" /> Established in 2005, the survey measures airlines and airports on specific criteria and ranks them to identify above or below average performance.<ref name="Air Cargo Excellence" />
The survey also shows exactly how airlines and airports are performing against an industry average and specifically highlights areas in need of improvement.<ref name="Air Cargo Excellence" />
==Past Magazine Titles== *''Air Transportation'' (1942–1968) *''Air Cargo'' (1969) *''Cargo Airlift'' (1969–1976) *''Air Cargo'' (1977–1982) *''Air Cargo World'' (1983–Present)
==Past Publishers== *John F. Budd *Robert R. Parrish *Martin B. Deutsch *Richard L. Gower *Susan Barbey *John F. Gorsuch *Steve Prince *JJ Hornblass (present)

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} '''Albert Bensimon''' (born 1948) is an [[Egyptian-Australian]] businessman from [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]]. He is most well known as the owner of [[Shiels Jewellers]]. He frequently appeared in television advertisements and became famous for his catchphrase "No Hoo-Haa".
Bensimon was born in [[Cairo, Egypt]]. His secondary education took place at the [[Christian Brothers College, Rose Bay|Christian Brothers College]] in [[Rose Bay, New South Wales]] followed by a stint at the [[London School of Economics]]. Bensimon is of [[Jewish]] descent.
In 1994, he helped to establish the [[Helpmann Academy]], named in honour of famous South Australian Sir [[Robert Helpmann]]. The academy is designed to promote the arts in South Australia. He was the first chairman and is still a member of its board.
At the [[South Australian state election, 2002|2002 South Australian state election]], Bensimon ran as a "No Hoo-Haa Party" candidate in the [[South Australian House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] seat of [[Electoral district of Adelaide|Adelaide]], receiving a primary vote of 2.4 percent (492 votes). His "how-to-vote" ticket indicated a first preference for the [[Liberal Party of Australia]]. Bensimon is also a donor to the Liberal Party.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.crikey.com.au/2002/02/03/labor-still-a-chance-to-take-the-final-state/|title=Labor still a chance to take the final state|date=3 February 2002|work=Crikey|access-date=17 March 2018}}</ref>
In 2006, Bensimon was rejected twice for membership of the gentlemen's club, [[The Adelaide Club]], which he claimed was due to [[anti-Semitism]]. This was denied by the Club president, who stated that it was "offensive" to suggest the club was racist and that it has "a diverse membership". In 2008, when another Egyptian-born Jewish businessman was accepted for membership, Bensimon claimed some credit for the move, saying "I broke the back of a small but influential element within the Adelaide Club."<ref>http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/adelaide-club-move-ends-jewish-tension/story-e6frea83-1111116926408</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/talks/natint/stories/s1583416.htm |work=National Interest |date=5 March 2006 |title=The Roundup |accessdate=29 June 2006 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Alfonso Valdés Cobián | image = A. Valdez.jpg |imagesize = 150px | caption = Alfonso Valdés Cobián | birth_date = June 23, 1890 | birth_place = [[Bayamon, Puerto Rico]] | death_date = February 14, 1988
[[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] | nationality = [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] | occupation = industrialist, banker, sportsman and politician | salary = | networth = | spouse = Grace García | children = | signature = | website = | footnotes = Valdés Cobián was the cofounder of Cervecería India, Inc., currently Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery. He served as Senator in the Puerto Rican Senate. He was also the owner of the "Indios de Mayagüez" (Mayagüez Indians), a basketball team. }} '''Alfonso Valdés Cobián''' {{Spanish name|''' Valdés'''|'''Cobián'''|plain=yes}} (June 23, 1890 - February 14, 1988), was an industrialist, banker, sportsman and politician. Valdés Cobián was a cofounder of [[Cervecería India]], Inc., currently Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery. ==Early years== Valdés Cobián was born in [[Bayamon, Puerto Rico]] to Ramon and Encarnación Cobián. When he was a child his family moved to the [[United States]] and lived in [[Manhattan]]. While living there he attended the [[Hamilton institute]], a preparatory school, and [[Columbia University]], where he received a degree in electrical engineering in 1911. The family returned to Puerto Rico and in 1910, his father, Ramón Valdés founded and organized the "Mayaguez Light, Power and Ice Company", a utility in the city of [[Mayagüez]]. The elder Valdés named Alfonso the company's vice president in 1915.Guía del Turismo en Mayagüez, Clásico de Mayagüez "La Cervecería India", (Spanish) The Government took over all power generation in the late 1930s and the company is now operated by "La Autoridad de Energía Eléctrica de Puerto Rico" (The Puerto Rico Electric Energy Authority). [https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/14/obituaries/alfonso-valdes-cobian-dies-in-san-juan-at-98.html New York Times; Published: February 14, 1988] ==Cervecería India== [[File:Admiral Leahy confers with Puerto Rican Officials.jpg|250px|left|thumb|[[William D. Leahy|Admiral Leahy]] confers with (left to right) Martínez Nadal, President of the Puerto Rican Senate, Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner standing; Fernando Geigel, City Manager of San Juan, P.R., '''Alfonso Valdez''', Puerto Rican Senator, Bolívar Pagan, Vice President of the Puerto Rican Senate, and Luis Obergh, counsel for Nadal]] Mayagüez is known as "La Ciudad de las Aguas Puras" (The City of the Pure Waters) because of the quality of its waters. The nickname originated because of the quality of the waters from the [[Yagüez River]]. The word "Yagüez" is [[Taíno language|Taino]] for "Place of pure and clear waters" .[http://www.aalcaldespr.com/mayaguez Mayaguez] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212171359/http://aalcaldespr.com/mayaguez |date=2009-02-12 }}, (Spanish) Valdés Cobián's brother Sabino, took a sample of the waters of Mayagüez to the Wallestein Laboratory in New York which confirmed the quality of the waters for the elaboration of beer. Valdés Cobián and his brothers, Sabino and [[Ramón Valdés Cobián|Ramón]] decided to build a brewery in Mayagüez and on November 2, 1937, they founded the [[Compañía Cervecera de Puerto Rico]] which was later renamed Cervecería India. The company competed with two other native beer breweries, "Real" and "Corona" (no relation to the Mexican beer), which no longer exist. Valdés Cobián, as chairman and president, successfully led his company converting it into Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery and manufacture of canned and bottled soft drinks. Besides his chairmanship of Cervecería India, Valdés Cobián held the [[Orange Crush]] soft-drink franchise and was president of the Ana Maria Sugar Company and the Insular Feed Mill. For 25 years he was the major stockholder and board chairman of the [[Banco Crédito y Ahorro Ponceño (building)|Banco Credito y Ahorro Ponceno]], which at the time was the second largest bank in Puerto Rico.[http://www.primerahora.com/noticia/otras_panorama/noticias/popular_se_agiganta/98500 "Popular se agiganta" - Primera Hora], (Spanish) ==Team owner== Valdés Cobián was a founder of the Puerto Rican winter baseball league and owned the [[Indios de Mayagüez]] (Mayagüez Indians), the most successful team in the history of the Puerto Rican League.[https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Indios_de_Mayag%C3%BCez Baseball Reference] The team was founded in 1938, and once the [[Puerto Rican Professional Baseball League]] (LBPPR in Spanish) was created, the Mayagüez team became a part of it.[http://1800beisbol.com/baseball/Deportes/Beisbol_Puerto_Rico/Historia_Beisbol_de_Puerto_Rico/ Historia Beisbol de Puerto Rico] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316221252/http://www.1800beisbol.com/baseball/Deportes/Beisbol_Puerto_Rico/Historia_Beisbol_de_Puerto_Rico/ |date=2008-03-16 }}, (Spanish) A management team led by Valdés Cobián owned the team during its initial years. ==Politician== Valdés Cobián was elected in 1917 to the [[Puerto Rico House of Representatives]] representing the district of Mayagüez, position in which he served until 1928. In 1928 he won his first of three terms as a member of the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]], and also became president of the Puerto Rican Republican Party. ==Later years== In 1960 he was president of the [[Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association]].{{Cite web | title = About Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association | publisher = Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association | url = http://www.prma.com/AM/Template.cfm?Section=About_PRMA&Template=/CM/HTMLDisplay.cfm&ContentID=3035 | accessdate = October 4, 2010}} Valdés Cobián lived in Villa Caparra, a San Juan suburb. On February 8, 1988, Valdés Cobián died in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]], after suffering a heart attack two days earlier, at the age of 98. Valdés Cobián was buried in Bayamón's Porta Coeli Cemetery. He was survived by his wife, Grace García, whom he married on August 14, 1939, two daughters, Grace Marie, Encarnita Quinlan and a son, Alfonso Jr., and five grandchildren. After his death, his wife became the president of brewery until her retirement in 2002, when her granddaughter, [[Camalia Valdés]] assumed the presidency of the company. ==Legacy== The City of Mayagüez honored his memory by naming the street where the Cervecería India Inc. is located Avenida (Blvd.) Alfonso Valdez.[http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/product-compint-0001152283-page.html Company profile] ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Biography}} *[[Cervecería India]] *[[Indios de Mayagüez]] *[[List of famous Puerto Ricans]] ==Notes== ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Valdes Cobian, Alfonso}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]] [[Category:Puerto Rican sports businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Columbia School of Engineering and Applied Science alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Businesspeople in brewing]] [[Category:Businesspeople in electricity]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Dr. Alireza Nasiri | image =Ministry of Cooperatives of Iran.jpg | caption = Alireza Nasiri as General Director of Planning and Development at Ministry of Cooperatives | office2 = General Director of Educational Support Department for Veteran Students [[University of Tehran]] | office1 = General Director of Planning and Development [[Ministry of Cooperatives]] | president1 = [[Mohammad Khatami]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|3|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Iran]] | nationality = Iranian | alma_mater = [[Iran University of Science and Technology]] | occupation = Consultant | profession = [[Industrial Engineer|Executive Industrial Management]] | term_start1 = 2004 | term_end1 = 2005 | term_start2 = 1999 | term_end2 = 2002 | office3 = Acting General Manager of Public Relations [[University of Tehran]] | term_start3 = 1998 | term_end3 = 1999 }}
'''Alireza Nasiri''' ({{lang-fa|عليرضا نصيري}}; born 21 March 1968) is an [[Iran]]ian academic, businessman and [[Technocracy#Characteristics|technocrat]]. '''Nasiri''' played a leading role in establishing online degree programs in Iran, founding the first online degree program in University of Tehran<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Alireza|first=Nasiri|year=2003|title=Suitable Organization Structure for Virtual Universities, Knowledge Management, No.61, Vol.16, 2003|url=|journal=Knowledge Management|volume=16|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> and projects on e-government in Iran.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nasiri|first=Alireza|year=2007|title=Driving Competitive Intelligence in the Virtual University|url=|journal=World Conference on E-Learning in Corporate, Government, Healthcare, and Higher Education, Canada|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> He is known as the father of commercial afforestation in Iran for starting a chain of commercial greenhouses to economically empower forest owners with [[Genetically modified crops|genetically modified]] Paulownia trees.<ref name="Paulownia">{{Cite web|url=http://iranpaulownia.ir/index.html|title=Paulownia|website=iranpaulownia.ir|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref> He was general director of planning and development in Iran's [[Ministry of Cooperatives (Iran)|Ministry of Cooperatives]] between 2004 and 2005 while also serving as acting Vice Minister.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gime.dufe.edu.cn/common_admin/UploadFiles/file/20131017/20131017084979407940.pdf |title=GIME Web |last= |first= |date= |website=Global Institute of Management and Economics |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322093738/http://www.gime.dufe.edu.cn/common_admin/UploadFiles/file/20131017/20131017084979407940.pdf |archivedate=2017-03-22 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2017-03-23 }}</ref>
He was on the board of directors of National Industrial (Melli) Shoe Co. and Darya Bandar Shipping Lines Co., among several other companies in Iran.<ref name=":2"/> Between 2011 and 2013 he was an instructor at [[Missouri State University]] [[Missouri State University Branch Campus Dalian|Dalian Campus]][http://china.missouristate.edu/cib/people.aspx] and published a study in the American Journal of Applied Sciences about the commercialization of e-learning in Iran.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nasiri|first=Alireza|year=Feb 2009|title=Environmental Factors Influence on Mobile Learning Business|url=|journal=American Journal of Applied Sciences, Feb 2009|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> '''Nasiri''' is a senior business management and innovation lecturer at Global Institute of Management and Economics in [[Dongbei University of Finance and Economics|DUFE]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gime.dufe.edu.cn/index_list.asp?types=4&id=610 |title=Study in China {{!}} English Taught Program in China - Global Institute of Management and Economics |date=2017-03-22 |accessdate=2017-03-22 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322093508/http://www.gime.dufe.edu.cn/index_list.asp?types=4&id=610 |archivedate=2017-03-22 }}</ref>
He is currently on the board of directors of [[Aras Green Economic Dawn|Aras GED]] which among other activities manages medium-sized commercial forests in Iran. Aras GED is also a consultant to large industrial companies on conducting business in Iran and the Middle East. The Tehran office of Aras GED Consulting is based out of the top floor of the SUNIR Co<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sunir.com/|title=SUNIR|last=|first=|date=|website=SUNIR Company|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020220110115/http://www.sunir.com/|archivedate=2002-02-20|deadurl=yes |accessdate=2017-03-23}}</ref> building in [[Tehran|Taleghani Avenue]] adjacent to the former American Embassy in Tehran.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sunir.com/|title=Sunir - Home|website=www.sunir.com|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref> In 2015 he supported investment and innovation in Iran's scientific fields as a means to create profitable business cycles in the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nasiri|first=Alireza|year=June 2015|title=Does Iran Scientific Development Support its Sustainable Development?|url=|journal=Journal of Sustainable Development, Vol 8, No 3|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> He also supported the cooperation of European companies with Iranian partners after the signing of the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|Iran nuclear deal]].<ref>{{Cite journal |doi= 10.1080/23311975.2016.1216727.pdf |title=Analysis of innovation management in German enterprises |doi-broken-date=2018-09-11}}</ref>
== Early life == Alireza Nasiri was born in Iran and finished highschool in the city of [[Qazvin]].[[File:Alireza_Nasiri.jpg|thumb|170x170px|Alireza Nasiri as general director of Educational Support Department for Veteran Students at [[University of Tehran]]. ]]
== Education == Nasiri graduated from Iran [[Iran University of Science and Technology|University of Science and Technology]] with a bachelor of Industrial Engineering in 1993 and began his profession as an industrial planner. In the 1990s the Iranian energy and engineering industry was just taking off, having to fill the vacuum left by the exit of companies such as [[Bechtel]] and withdrawal of American blue collar engineers from Iran such as [[Bell Engineering Center|Bell Engineers]] from the times of [[Richard Nixon]], a large need for industrial engineers developed in Iran. Nasiri joined many others who studied at the [[Iran University of Science and Technology|University of Science and Technology]] by completing the [[Iranian University Entrance Exam|Iranian Concours]], the Iranian equivalent of the [[SAT]].
In 2000 he acquired a M.Sc in Executive Management from the Industrial Management Institute (IMI) of Iran in Tehran and started working as an executive manager specializing in industry and engineering. [[File:1st_National_Exhibition_in_IT_and_E-City.jpg|thumb|Launching of 1st National Exhibition on IT in Iran launching E-City plan.|192x192px]]In 2010 he gained a PhD in Management Science and Engineering from the Dalian University of Technology in China and became an academic instructor with extensive experience in management and various industrial planning.
== Career == [[File:Online_Degrees_in_Iran.jpg|thumb|239x239px|First workshops held in Iran on the launch and management of online degree programs in University of Tehran.]]Nasiri began his career as an industrial planner in 1993 by working on industrial design projects. Later by 1999 he moved towards consulting and management, using his knowledge of industry and management techniques to improve the internal policy of industrial companies in Iran. He had a full-time career at the [[University of Tehran]] and often consulted companies in various industries and was appointed to several board of directors in those companies. Nasiri was among others part of a push to start a commercial ICT sector in Iran.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />[https://web.archive.org/web/20090130021742/http://www.austrade.gov.au/ICT-to-Iran/default.aspx]
Since 1998 he worked as acting general manager in the University of Tehran Public Relations office until 1999, working as chief executive of the influential Tehran University Monthly Press (ماهنامه دانشگاه تهران). During that time he was also consultant to the [[chief executive officer]] at Melli National Industrial Shoes Co. and in 2000 became a member of the board at Melli Industrial Shoe. In the same period between 1999 and 2001 he consulted [[Hamid Rahmani]] in [[Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization of Iran|National Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization of Iran]] which is in charge of tourism and export of Iranian cultural products and is regarded as an autonomous [[Politics of Iran|Iranian government ministry]].
In 2002 he shifted departments and his full-time job at University of Tehran changed to the General Director of Educational Support Department for Veteran Students, shortened as Isargaran, in the University of Tehran.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://shahed.ut.ac.ir/advers.aspx?id=11331 |title=اداره کل امور شاهد و ایثارگر دانشگاه تهران |date=2014-03-14 |accessdate=2017-03-22 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314114754/http://shahed.ut.ac.ir/advers.aspx?id=11331 |archivedate=2014-03-14 }}</ref>
In 2003 he launched Iran's first online degree program based out of University of Tehran.<ref name=":0" /> In 2003 online degree programs were an unexplored subject in Iran and the Middle East, and Nasiri managed workshops on the launch and management of online degrees in Iran at the University of Tehran and the 1st National Exhibition on IT and launched the E-City project.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Nasiri|first=Alireza|year=2004|title=Managing Virtual Universities and E-learning Centers, Faculty of Management, University of Tehran Press, Iran, 2004|url=|journal=University of Tehran Press|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> In 2004 he became a member of board at Darya Bandar Shipping Lines Co. In the same year he exited the University of Tehran and started working full-time at the [[Ministry of Cooperatives (Iran)|Ministry of Cooperatives]] as General Director of Planning and Development during the tenure of [[Mohammad Khatami|President Khatami]].<ref name=":2" /> While serving as director of planning and development he was the acting vice minister in the absence of [[Bahman Salehi]].
== Commercializing Forestation in Iran == [[File:Commercial Forestation in Iran.jpg|thumb|244x244px|Commercial forest planted in Janat Shahr by Aras GED.]] [[File:Commercial forestation in Iran in an artificial forest managed by Aras GED in Shiraz.jpg|thumb|Commercial forest of Aras GED's genetically modified trees in Shiraz. |221x221px]] After exiting the [[Ministry of Cooperatives (Iran)|Ministry of Cooperatives]] in 2005 he began a PhD course on Management Science and Engineering in China, Dalian.
After completing his PhD in the city of Dalian he was impressed by Chinese city planning utilizing green spaces as both a decorative and commercial tool to fight pollution and soil damage in the coastal city of [[Dalian]]. He began a campaign to solve Iran's pollution, deforestation and green city planning problem using commercial forestation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iranpaulownia.ir/Forest.html|title=ایران پالونیا|website=iranpaulownia.ir|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref>
The effort would be supported by a series of greenhouses which produced genetically modified trees in a dozen locations across Iran. During this campaign Aras Green Economic Dawn ({{lang-fa|عصر اقتصاد سبز ارس}}), or Aras GED, was established to manage the commercialization of forestation in Iran and cut down on the import of paper into the country which amounted to a billion dollar industry in 2013.<ref name="Paulownia" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://marketpublishers.com/report/industry/light_industry/pulp-n-paper_industry_in_iran_business_report.html|title=Pulp-and-paper industry in Iran: Business Report 2017|website=marketpublishers.com|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref>
The campaign had many setbacks in areas outside of [[Tehran]], but for the most part has succeeded in making artificial forests commercially viable and profitable for forest owners in Iran. By creating economic value for forests with [[Genetically modified tree|modified trees]] land owners would be part of a countrywide push towards [[Afforestation|commercial forestation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iranpaulownia.ir/Forest2.html|title=ایران پالونیا|website=iranpaulownia.ir|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref>
Aras GED's commercial afforestation began in several large cities in Iran. Namely [[Tehran]], [[Shiraz]], [[Tabriz]], [[Mashhad|Masshad]], [[Bandar Abbas]], [[Bandar-e Anzali|Anzali]] and [[Ardabil|Ardebil]]. Artificial forests were also planted in less urban locations such as Janat Shahr.
The genetically modified nature of the trees made them both heat and chill resistant which was important in Iran's [[Geography of Iran|diverse weather environment]]. However Aras GED came up with a solution that would solve Iran's forest and pollution problem with a single tree that could be planted in the cold hills of [[Ardabil|Ardebil]] and also the hot valleys of [[Sistan and Baluchestan Province|Sistan and Baluchestan]]. Depending on a variety of factors from the ground's [[red soil]] content to moisture, the Aras GED tree grows anywhere between 2 and 3 meters in the first 7 months of planting.
Using experience gained in the first few years of the commercial forestation campaign in Iran, the company will start to provide a [[Environmentalism|green environment]] [[warranty]] with every Aras GED tree sold across Iran in order to make commercial forestry in Iran more widespread.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iranpaulownia.ir/Forest2.html|title=Iran Paulownia|last=|first=|date=|website=Iran Paulownia|accessdate=}}</ref>
== Consulting in China == [[File:Shiraz Metro Authority and Governor of Fars.jpg|thumb|Shiraz Metro authority and Governor of Fars on a visit to DLRC. |240x240px]] Nasiri consulted several Iranian companies doing business in China and several Chinese companies doing business in Iran. Among these companies was [[Shiraz Metro]] which purchased rolling stock from [[China Railway Construction Corporation Limited|China National Railway Company]] and its subsidiary in Dalian, [[CNR Dalian|DLRC.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/urban/single-view/view/shiraz-metro-line-1-opens.html|title=Railway Gazette|last=|first=|date=|work=Railway Gazette|accessdate=}}</ref> under an investment and sales agreement with the municipal government of [[Fars Province|Fars]]. Nasiri represented the [[Shiraz Metro]] company in Dalian.
Since 2016 Nasiri's consulting office is based out of the top floor of the SUNIR Co building. SUNIR Co is the 8th global private contractor for electricity transmission and distribution and is based in Tehran.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sunir.com/About-Sunir/Certificates|title=Sunir - Certificates|website=www.sunir.com|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sunir.com/About-Sunir/Message-from-Managing-Director|title=Sunir - Message from Managing Director|website=www.sunir.com|accessdate=2017-03-22}}</ref>
==Board of directors== In 2000 he joined the board of directors at National Industrial Shoe Co.
In 2004 he served as a member of the board of directors at Darya Bandar Shipping Lines Co.
Alireza Nasiri is currently a member of the board at Aras GED.

The '''American Association of Christian Counselors, Inc.''' ('''AACC''') is the largest organization of [[Christian counseling|Christian counselors]] in the world.<ref name="lang">Brian Lang, Bill Wilson, ''A christian parents' guide to making the internet family friendly'', [[Nashville, Tennessee]]: [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]], 1999 [https://books.google.com/books?id=P7rni7b8zFcC&pg=PT50&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=AIobTqbZCeHt0gH5yuTbBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref>
==Overview== It is a [[corporation]] <ref>{{cite web |title=Business Entity Details 06243554 |url=https://sccefile.scc.virginia.gov/Business/0624355 |website=State Corporation Commission |publisher=Commonwealth of Virginia |accessdate=28 October 2018 |quote=SCC ID: 06243554; Entity Type: Corporation; Jurisdiction of Formation: VA; Date of Formation/Registration: 9/24/2004}}</ref> headquartered in [[Forest, Virginia]], United States.<ref>James V. Geisendorfer, ''Religion in America: a directory'', [[Brill Archive]], 1983, p. 4 [https://books.google.com/books?id=5A0VAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA4&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=zIgbTq3yG6Hf0QGY9dXgBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref> AACC, as it is often called, creates the largest gathering of Christian counselors once per year in North America with annual conferences that often exceed 5,000 attendees. Speakers for these events include, [[Henry Cloud|Dr. Henry Cloud]], [[John Townsend (author)|Dr. John Townsend]], Gary Smalley, Larry Crabb, T.D. Jakes, Ron Hawkins, John Trent, Emmerson Eggrich, Joni Tada, Arch Harte, John Eldredge, and a host of other popular Christian writers. AACC is under the direction of Dr. Tim Clinton and celebrates their 25th anniversary as a professional trade association in 2011. They were previously headquartered in [[Fairfax, Virginia]].<ref>Randolph K. Sanders, ''Christian counseling ethics: a handbook for therapists, pastors & counselors'', [[Westmond, Illinois]]: [[InterVarsity Press]], 1997, p. 390 [https://books.google.com/books?id=bMBog7pMvCsC&pg=PA390&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=spcbToSkFcTd0QGLraX8Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref> It has about nearly 50,000 members.<ref>Timothy Clinton, Archibald D. Harte, ''Caring for People God's Way: Personal and Emotional Issues, Addictions, Grief, and Trauma'', Nashville, Tennessee: Thomas Nelson, 2006 p. 506 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ptYRUlKFiaQC&pg=PA506&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=spcbToSkFcTd0QGLraX8Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CFMQ6AEwBjgU#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref> It publishes two [[Magazine|journal]]s: ''Christian Counseling Today'' and ''Marriage and Family: A Christian Journal''.<ref name="koenig">Harold George Koenig, ''Handbook of religion and mental health'', [[Amsterdam, Netherlands]]: [[Elsevier]], 1998, p. 342 [https://books.google.com/books?id=504GYYj1O3kC&pg=PA342&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=AIobTqbZCeHt0gH5yuTbBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref> It has adopted a [[code of ethics]] used for Christian counseling.<ref name="russell">Lori Ann Russell-Chapin, Ted Chapin, ''Clinical Supervision: Theory and Practice'', [[Stamford, Connecticut]]: [[Cengage Learning]], 2011, p. 195 [https://books.google.com/books?id=JnUNsT4oDVUC&pg=PA195&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=AIobTqbZCeHt0gH5yuTbBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref><ref name="siang">Siang-Yang Tan, ''Counseling and Psychotherapy: A Christian Perspective'', [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]: [[Baker Academic]], 2011, p. 375 [https://books.google.com/books?id=wtQV4u2yLHIC&pg=PA375&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=zIgbTq3yG6Hf0QGY9dXgBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFcQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref><ref name="clinton">Tim Clinton, Ron Hawkins, ''The Popular Encyclopedia of Christian Counseling: An Indispensable Tool for Helping People with Their Problems'', [[Irvine, California]]: [[Harvest House Publishers]], 2011, p. 77 [https://books.google.com/books?id=TCImZOSzPOgC&pg=PA77&dq=%22American+Association+of+Christian+Counselors%22&hl=en&ei=zIgbTq3yG6Hf0QGY9dXgBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Association%20of%20Christian%20Counselors%22&f=false]</ref> In 2014 AACC amended its code of ethics to eliminate the promotion of [[conversion therapy]] for homosexuals and encouraged them to be celibate instead.<ref name="religionnews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.religionnews.com/2014/08/04/gay-christian-celibate-changing-face-homosexuality-debate/ |title=Gay, Christian and ... celibate: The changing face of the homosexuality debate - Religion News Service |publisher=Religionnews.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-07}}</ref>

[[Motorcycle parts|Motorcycle Parts]] |products = |revenue = |net_income = |homepage = [http://www.arrow.it/ www.arrow.it] }} '''Arrow Special Parts''' is one of the world's leading motorcycle exhaust manufacturers. ==History== It was founded in 1985 in Italy when Giorgio Giannelli realised his dream of creating a company whose main purpose was the production of highly performing exhaust systems. After a couple of years, the first great success arrived with Belgian rider [[Georges Jobé|Jobé]] winning the 500cc Motocross World Championship. Since 2000 Arrow has won more than 20 World Titles, in [[Superbike World Championship|SBK]], [[Supersport World Championship|SS]], [[Motocross|MX]] and [[Supermoto]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arrow.it/eng/website/|title=Arrow Special Parts company profile }} ==Today== In 2008 alone, the firm added 3 more Crowns: [[FIM Motocross World Championship|MX1 World Championship]], with [[David Philippaerts]], in [[Supermoto|S2 Supermoto World Championship]] with Adrien Chareyre and [[Supersport World Championship|SS World Championship]] with [[Andrew Pitt]], cementing its place as a leader in the market.{{cite web|url=http://www.arrow.it/eng/website/|title=Arrow Special Parts}} Today the firm also produces other key motorcycle parts including [[steering damper]]s and competition footpegs. ==See also == {{Portal|Italy|Companies}} *[[List of Italian companies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Automotive companies of Italy]] [[Category:Motorcycle accessory manufacturers]] [[Category:Italian brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1985]] {{Italy-company-stub}} {{motorcycle-racing-stub}}

[[File:Zak WestBank.jpg|thumb|250px|Bashar Masri with [[United States Trade and Development Agency|U.S. Trade and Development Agency]] Director [[Leocadia I. Zak]] and an architect at the [[Rawabi]] site.]] '''Bashar Masri''' (/{{lang-ar|بشار مصري}}/ February 4, 1961) is a [[Palestinian American]] entrepreneur and successful business man, he is the founder and [[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]] of Massar International, since its establishment in 1994. He is the founder and visionary behind the high-tech "[[Rawabi|Rawabi City]]", Palestine's first planned city, he is also the founder and currently the managing director of Bayti Real Estate Investment Company that built the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402495&privcapId=107355227|title=Executive Profile: Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He founded and manages the first Palestinian equity fund, a 90 million investment initiative known as "Siraj Fund".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He's on the list of the "Top Ten Richest People of Palestine in 2016" with net worth estimated at 1.5 Billion Dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.richincomeways.com/luxury/top-ten-richest-people-of-palestine-in-2016/|title=Top Ten Richest People of Palestine In 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Early life == Masri was born in [[Nablus]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] and raised there.<ref>[http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2011/02/23/1298437200_20 Palestinian-American Entrepreneur Re-Envisions West Bank Development]</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=West Bank: Palestinians’ first planned city will offer modern space |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/11/04/west-bank-palestinians-first-planned-city-will-offer-modern-space/ |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}</ref> After leaving Nablus, Masri continued his education first in Egypt then moved to the United States, [[Virginia]] where he Graduated from [[Virginia Polytechnic University]] with a B.S. in [[Chemical engineering|Chemical Engineering]] in 1983.<ref>{{cite news|title=The first (planned) Palestinian city |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1259243039024&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=30 November 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2009/11/03/1257224400_14|title=BUILDING IN THE WEST BANK: An Interview with Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He worked in a number of countries before he decided to return to Palestine and settle there in the mid-1994, among them the [[Saudi Arabia|Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]], the [[United States|United States of America]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. and with a background in [[management consulting]] and [[industrial management]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402495&privcapId=107355227|title=Executive Profile: Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
On a regional level, Masri has spearheaded large and economically significant investment projects, including [[affordable housing]] [[Community|communities]] in [[Morocco]], commercial and residential developments in [[Jordan]], and a residential real estate project in [[Egypt]]. Massar Company under Masri's management currently has multiple businesses in [[Morocco]], [[Jordan]], [[Egypt]] and [[Serbia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Masri is the father of two daughters: Tamara Masri and Dina Masri.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2009/11/03/1257224400_14|title=BUILDING IN THE WEST BANK: An Interview with Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Business in Palestine ==
=== Al-Ayyam Newspaper === After Masri came back from [[Washington, D.C.|Washington DC]] to [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] in Mid-1990s to establish himself in his home country, he started by founding Palestinians daily newspaper "Al-Ayyam Newspaper (/Arabic: جريدة الأيام/)" and was its publisher. Al Ayyam is today the second largest newspaper in Palestine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ac890172-2024-11e3-9a9a-00144feab7de|title=Peace dividends|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Massar International Ltd === In 1994, Masri founded and now is the Chairman of the board of Massar International,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.massar.com/?TemplateId=info&PageId=2&MenuId=13&Lang=1|title=Chairman letter|last1=|first1=|date=17 February 2018|work=|accessdate=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|location=}}</ref> since the establishment of Massar, he has been one of the most prominent figures promoting private sector development and growth in Palestine.He has dedicated his life to establishing, investing, transforming, networking, training and building what is now a widely known group of businesses bridging Palestine to global technologies, knowledge, know-how and industry best practices. In the past decade, he has launched businesses in [[financial services]], [[real estate]], [[Media (communication)|media]] and [[communication]]s, retail businesses, [[agribusiness]] and [[information technology]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=107354853|title=Company Overview of Massar International|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
According to Massar International's website, these companies are either owned by Massar International or Massar International has invested in them:[http://www.massar.com]
==== The Real Estate sector ====
# Bayti Real Estate - Palestine # Bayti Investment - Morocco # Palestine Investment and Development - Palestine # Tamleek for Investment and Real Estate Development - Jordan # Al-Quds Holding - Palestine
==== Financial Services ====
# Sahem Trading and Investment - Palestine # Siraj Fund Management - Palestine # The National Bank (TNB) - Palestine # Palestine Mortgage and Housing Corporate (PMHS) - Palestine # The Palestinian Company for Rental and Leasing (Pallease) - Palestine # Al-Tadamon Al-Arabi Brokerage (TA-Invest) - Egypt # Energo Broker a.d. Beograd - Serbia
==== Information Technology Sector ====
# ASAL Technologies - Palestine # Call u Communication - Palestine # WebTeb - Palestine # Bader ICT Incubator - Palestine
==== Media and Communication ====
# Publicis Zoom - Palestine # High Definition Vision (HD Vision) - Palestine # Al-Ayyam Printing, Press, Publication & Distribution - Palestine
==== Agriculture ====
# Harvest Export - Palestine # Nakheel Palestine for Agriculture Investment - Palestine
==== Other Sectors ====
# Massar Consulting and Technical Services - Palestine # Alpha International for Research, Polling and Informatics - Palestine # Travel Masters - Jordan # Decorx for Wood Industrial - Palestine # Palestinian Logistics and Distribution Services (Wassel) - Palestine # Ziadah Architects and Engineers - Palestine # PalGaz for Gas Distribution and Services - Palestine # The Palestinian Company for Hospitality Services - Palestine
=== Rawabi City & Bayti Real Estate === Not only was Masri the visionary and founder of Rawabi City, he also oversees the construction and development of the city. Rawabi City is a [[High tech|high-tech]] [[Planned community|planned city]], the first of its kind in Palestine, and it was funded fully by the private sector, Rawabi is considered the largest private sector investment is Palestine's history, the construction of the city so far has cost 1.4 billion dollars. Rawabi is being constructed by Bayti Real Estate Investment Company that is jointly owned by [[Qatar]]i Diar Real Estate Investment Company and Massar International.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rawabi.ps/bayti/about_bayti.php|title=About Bayti|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> With its more than 6,000 housing units built to serve families from multiple demographics, state-of-the-art infrastructure, and an emerging commercial hub, the city has already made a positive economic and social impact on Palestinians and it is constructed to provide housing for 25,000 person in its first stage and 40,000 people when it is done.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rawabi.ps/press_show.php?id=6|title=PRESS RELEASE|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.pnn.ps/2017/05/17/video-rawabi-city-opens-biggest-shopping-center-in-palestine/|title=Video: Rawabi city opens biggest shopping center in Palestine|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Not only does the city provide affordable housing options it is also the second biggest generator of jobs, after the [[Palestinian government|Palestinian Government]], providing between 8,000 and 10,000 job opportunity a year for [[construction worker]]s,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/monicawang/2016/07/06/one-mans-dream-city-rises-in-the-occupied-west-bank/#bd1b258732d0|title=One Man's Dream City Rises In The Occupied West Bank|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in addition to thousands of job opportunities, whether in Massar International companies that moved there, or in the different shops and entertainment facilities the city provides.
Masri aims for the City of Rawabi to be the [[Silicon Valley]] and the Tech Hub for the [[State of Palestine]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/with-all-his-chips-in-palestinian-businessman-aims-to-build-silicon-rawabi/|title=With all his chips in, Palestinian businessman aims to build ‘Silicon Rawabi’|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in tireless attempts to provide spaces for promising [[technology]] and technology related [[Startup company|startups]] at the city, and businesses from inside and outside of [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] to the city.
=== Siraj Fund Management Company === Masri founded and manages the first Palestinian equity fund, a 90 million investment initiative known as "Siraj Fund" in 2003, and the company's first fun "Siraj Palestine Fund I" was launched in February 2011,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=108755386|title=Company Overview of Siraj Fund Management Company|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the company was founded for the sole purpose of managing investment funds in Palestine. The company focuses on promising startups and [[capital investments]] in small and medium sized [[Business|enterprises]] in the sectors of [[information]] and [[communication]] [[technology services]], [[energy]], [[agriculture]], [[clean technology]], [[Health care|healthcare]], [[logistics]], [[education]], [[manufacturing]], [[transport]]ation, [[construction]] and [[financial services]]. Siraj's [[investment]]<nowiki/>s in these companies range between $250,000 and $12 million, and plans on expanding in the [[MENA|MENA region]] in the future.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=108755411|title=Company Overview of Siraj Palestine Fund I|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Awards and Positions == Masri is the former Palestinian Chapter Chairman of the [[Young Presidents' Organization]] (YPO).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402476&privcapId=107354853&previousCapId=107354853&previousTitle=Massar%20International|title=Bashar Fayeq Masri: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> He was named as a "[[Global Leader of Tomorrow]]" by the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref>[http://www.africaintelligence.com/MCE/businessmen/2011/02/17/bashar-masri%2C88135127-BRC-login African intelligence 17/2/2011]</ref> Masri serves on the Board of Directors of the Palestine Development and Investment Company (PADICO),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.padico.com/en/about-padico/238.html|title=BOARD MEMBER AND A REPRESENTATIVE OF MASSAR INTERNATIONAL INVESTMENT GROUP|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> and the Board of Trustees of [[An-Najah National University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.najah.edu/en/about/governance/board-trustees/|title=Board of trustees|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Masri is a member of the Deans’ Council of the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hks.harvard.edu/more/about-us/leadership-administration/deans-office/deans-council|title=Dean's Council|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
Fortune Magazine ranked Masri #38 on its list of "The World's 50 Greatest Leaders".<ref>{{cite web|title=The World's 50 Greatest Leaders|url=http://fortune.com/longform/worlds-greatest-leaders-2018/#bashar|publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=2018-05-03|language=en|date=April 19, 2018}}</ref>

'''Birra Ichnusa''', or simply '''Ichnusa''', is the name of a popular [[Sardinia]]n-made beer, which is brewed in [[Assemini]], a town near the Sardinian capital [[Cagliari]]. It is named after the [[Latin]]ized ancient name Sardinia, ''Hyknusa''.
Birra Ichnusa is a [[lager]] (4.7% ABV) with a [[hops|hoppy taste]].
Founded in 1912, Birra Ichnusa is now owned by [[Heineken International]]. Birra Ichnusa Special is a lager with 5.6% and Ichnusa Cruda a non pasteurized lager with 4.9% alc. Serving temperatures for all of them is 3 °C. A [[Zwickel]]-style, unfiltered, 'Ichnusa Non Filtrata' (5.0% ABV) is also available.<ref name="RateBeerNF">{{cite web |title=RateBeer |url=https://www.ratebeer.com/beer/ichnusa-non-filtrata/512213/ |website=www.ratebeer.com |accessdate=10 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
<gallery> Birra Ichnusa, 66 cl..JPG|Birra Ichnusa Ichnusa Speciale.jpg|Ichnusa Speciale Ichnusa Cruda.JPG|Ichnusa Cruda </gallery>
